awd_titl_txt: SBIR Phase I:  Production of natural sun-protective compounds
awd_abstract_narration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) project is the development of sustainably produced, effective natural sunscreen compound found in marine organisms for skincare applications.  The World Health Organization estimates that one in every three cancers diagnosed is a skin cancer.  The prevalence of skin cancer, and the threat of photoaging, is driving growth in the global market for sun protection products, which is predicted to reach over $7 B by 2020.  However, many chemical sunscreen ingredients on the market today have been shown to be harmful to the environment and/or to have adverse health effects.  The goal is to produce a previously identified marine sunscreen compound, gadusol, in an economical and sustainable yeast biomanufacturing system, and replace problematic sunscreen ingredients in current use. 

This SBIR Phase I project proposes to develop a sustainable means of producing a natural, marine-based sunscreen ingredient for skincare applications. This project focuses on increasing yields and recovery of gadusol, a fish-derived UV-B-absorbing sunscreen, by using the tools of microbial fermentation and synthetic biology. The gadusol biosynthetic pathway was recently introduced into yeast.  The key technical objectives of his project are to improve gadusol yields, evaluate yeast-produced gadusol use in skin care products, and develop methods for purification that will be applicable to large-scale production.  The anticipated outcome of this project is a new and underutilized sunscreen compound derived from natural sources that has the potential to provide UV protection without the health and environmental risks associated with current commercial ingredients.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Technology, Innovation, and Partnerships

por.por_cntn:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) project was the development of a sustainably produced, effective natural sunscreen compound found in marine organisms for skincare applications. The World Health Organization estimates that one in every three cancers diagnosed is a skin cancer. The prevalence of skin cancer, and the threat of photoaging, is driving growth in the global market for sun protection products, which is predicted to reach over $7 B by 2020. However, many chemical sunscreen ingredients on the market today have been shown to be harmful to the environment and/or to have adverse health effects. The goal was to establish production of gadusol, a previously identified marine sunscreen compound, in an economical and sustainable yeast biomanufacturing system in order to replace problematic sunscreen ingredients in current use. 

This SBIR Phase I project focused on increasing yields and recovery of gadusol, a fish-derived UV-B-absorbing sunscreen by using the tools of microbial fermentation and synthetic biology. In addition, a characterization of the commercial suitability of gadusol was undertaken. A 6-fold increase in gadusol yield was achieved and a simple purification procedure was developed that provided greater than 90% purity. Gadusol was found to be stable during storage as a dry preparation with no evidence of degradation products detected after 30 days. In liquid, greater than 90% activity was retained after 30 days. Gadusol was found to be odorless in prototype formulation, was not toxic to E. colior to mammalian cells, and did not exhibit mutagenicity in the Ames test. Collaborations were developed with industrial partners interested in furthering the commercial development of gadusol as a viable replacement for problematic synthetic sunscreens.

 


Last Modified: 06/13/2019
Modified by: Khaled H Almabruk
